author: By Alexa Brazilian
title: So Long, Pavlova. Trifle Is the Dessert of the Summer.
description: In Britain and beyond, chefs are embracing the traditional English sweet — and taking it to new heights.
content: In classic British fashion, the trifle — perhaps the most quintessentially English dessert — is an almost comical understatement, its name suggesting a light snack when the dish itself is an indulgent, multilayered, alcohol-soaked production. The moniker was more accurate in the 16th century, when it referred to a simple pudding made from clotted cream mixed with sugar and rosewater. But in the Victorian era, the trifle evolved into a more elaborate creation: leftover cake or biscuits piled into a generous, footed glass bowl, saturated with a fortified white wine known as “sack” and sandwiched between fresh fruit, custard, jelly (gelatin made from calves’ feet), syllabub (alcohol-infused whipped cream) and a precursor to modern-day sprinkles made from caraway seeds coated in colored sugar. According to the English food historian Ivan Day, while the exact origins of the confection are unknown, it likely evolved from an amalgamation of several desserts. “On an aristocratic table in 18th-century England you’d have a range of different sweets: biscuits, which they dipped into wineglasses, jellies, custards, syllabub and coated caraway seeds to freshen breath and aid with digestion,” he says. “Trifle became all those dishes mixed together in a bowl.”

author: By Kate Kelly
title: With Long Hours and a No-Fail Mission, the Secret Service Tries to Make Do
description: The agency charged with protecting presidents and foreign leaders has its largest ever budget, but employees say it is still unable to recruit and retain enough people to carry the load.
content: Over the years, whenever the United States Secret Service’s lack of resources has been an issue, agents invoke a tongue-in-cheek motto: We do more with less.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery and Jill Cowan
title: Clear Encampments? Mind Your Own Business, Los Angeles Says.
description: In California, Gov. Gavin Newsom’s declaration urging cities to clear homeless camps met its strongest opposition in Los Angeles.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom appeared this week wearing work gloves and Ray-Ban sunglasses as he hauled a garbage bag from under a freeway overpass in California. His message was obvious: He wanted state and local officials to clear out homeless encampments, just as he was doing, and he had signed an executive order to spur them into action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Silent No More, Harris Seeks Her Own Voice Without Breaking With Biden
description: The vice president’s expressions of concern for Palestinian suffering marked a shift in emphasis from the president’s statements as she moved to establish herself as the leader of her party.
content: After meeting with Israel’s prime minister this week, Vice President Kamala Harris said she “will not be silent.” She was referring to her concerns about Palestinian suffering in the Gaza war, but in a way it was a larger declaration of independence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malachy Browne, Devon Lum and Alexander Cardia
title: Speculation Swirls About What Hit Trump. An Analysis Suggests It was a Bullet
description: An absence of medical records or official accounts has stirred confusion, but a Times video and trajectory analysis indicates a bullet, not debris, wounded the former president.
content: Nearly two weeks after the assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump, there’s still no official report from the Trump campaign or from state or federal governments about what caused the wound on his right ear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Behind the Democrats’ Fight Over Lina Khan’s Future
description: A debate over whether the F.T.C. chair should stay reflects broader anxiety over how Kamala Harris would regulate business.
content: News that Reid Hoffman, the billionaire LinkedIn co-founder and major Democratic donor, wants Vice President Kamala Harris, if she wins in November, to replace Lina Khan as chair of the F.T.C. provoked outrage on the left. Senator Bernie Sanders, independent of Vermont, called it “unacceptable,” and Tim Wu, the Columbia Law School professor and former Biden antitrust official, demanded that the Harris campaign return Hoffman’s donations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: A New Batman Is Less a Dark Knight Than a ‘Weird and Creepy’ One
description: “Batman: Caped Crusader,” a new animated series, is not concerned with making its hero likable — either to the citizens of Gotham or to its audience.
content: The story of Batman has been told in comic books and onscreen many times. But if there’s one person who should get the chance to tell it again, it is Bruce Timm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Natalie Kitroeff
title: A Fake Trip and a Stunning Betrayal Landed Top Cartel Leaders in U.S. Hands
description: Ismael Zambada García and Joaquín Guzmán López helped run the Sinaloa Cartel, one of the most dominant criminal groups in Mexico.
content: The arrest in the United States of two top leaders of the Sinaloa drug cartel came after what initial accounts suggest was a dramatic betrayal that saw one of the men, a son of the notorious drug lord known as El Chapo, lure the other under false pretenses onto a plane that delivered them both into the hands of American law enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: For Billy Joel Fans, a New York Night to Remember
description: Thousands of people piled into Madison Square Garden on Thursday to hear Billy Joel’s catalog of hits in the final show of his long residency at the arena.
content: Lori Umbrino saw her first Billy Joel concert at Shea Stadium in Queens in 1990. More than three decades later, she stood with her two children outside Madison Square Garden on Thursday evening, each wearing a T-shirt from the singer’s concerts across the years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a ’90s coming-of-age tale from India, a Turkish noir set in a zoo, a Romanian drama about provincial politics and more.
content: Stream it on Ovid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Orr
title: The Climate Is Changing. The Olympics Need to Change, Too.
description: Organizers must reduce the event’s carbon footprint.
content: The organizers of the Paris Olympic Games have outdone their predecessors in trying to make the Games the most sustainable in the decades since climate change became a concern. But with an estimated 11 million tourists converging on the City of Light for the Olympics, including 1.5 million from abroad, the Games can only be so green.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Jerry Miller, 81, Lauded Guitarist With ’60s Band Moby Grape, Dies
description: He drew praise for his blues-inflected fretwork as his critically acclaimed band rode high, if briefly, during San Francisco’s Summer of Love.
content: Jerry Miller, an acclaimed guitarist who emerged from the Pacific Northwest club circuit to make his mark on San Francisco’s psychedelic rock scene in the 1960s as a founding member of the lauded, if star-crossed, band Moby Grape, died on Sunday at his home in Tacoma, Wash. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: How Some States Are Making It Harder to Register Voters
description: Florida and some other states have put restrictions on voter registration drives, often with stiff fines that are dissuading some civic groups from taking part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Top Real Estate Agent Faces Another Claim of Sexual Assault
description: A fourth woman filed a lawsuit against Oren Alexander, once a star agent of luxury real estate.
content: An actress and comedian says she was drugged and sexually assaulted by Oren Alexander, a top luxury real estate agent who is facing a string of accusations that he and two of his brothers sexually assaulted women — allegations that had been whispered throughout the high-end real estate industry for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 8: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by Aug. 2 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced by Aug. 14.
content: Welcome to the eighth week of our 15th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Lady Gaga Opens With an Ode to French Cabaret
description: The ceremony will also provide a showcase for Aya Nakamura, a French-Malian singer, and a range of musical styles including disco, French hip-hop and zouk from the French Caribbean.
content: Lady Gaga was pure panache in the opening production number of the opening ceremony: a tribute to cabaret with “Mon Truc en Plumes” (“My Thing With Feathers”), a cabaret standard originally performed by Zizi Jeanmaire. Flaunting a pink feathered pom-pop, and surrounded by dancers with plenty more of them, she flaunted her tangy voice and some strutting moves, and also played piano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: The One Thing Watermelon Experts Do to Pick Sweet Ones
description: It’s not a myth: You really do need to slap them and listen carefully.
content: Don’t worry, it’s not just you. It’s hard to pick a good watermelon. So much of what determines its sweetness is beyond your control. And what is in your control may go against your instincts. It’s a challenge to your sense of free will, an exercise in letting go, a gamble at the market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven R. Weisman
title: Trump Ignores the Ruinous History of Tariffs
description: The former president is praising the era when tariffs fueled the federal budget — and also caused social dislocation and financial instability.
content: Donald Trump’s economic panacea is to impose over-the-top tariffs on all imports, potentially generating enough revenue to eliminate the federal income tax. It is hardly an innovative idea. On the contrary, if enacted, it would return our postmodern economy to that of the Gilded Age of the late 19th century, to economic policies favoring the wealthy over the poor and middle class, when tariffs were the main source of government revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: After Urging Israel to End War, Trump Says He Has ‘Good Relationship’ With Netanyahu
description: Former President Donald J. Trump also attacked Vice President Kamala Harris as insufficiently supportive of Israel after his meeting with the country’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, who has for months urged Israel to end the war in Gaza as quickly as possible, insisted that he and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel were on good terms after the two met on Friday in Palm Beach, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender and Chris Cameron
title: The Stages of Vance’s Political Conversion
description: A review of JD Vance’s writings and interviews reveals the gradual, complicated process behind his conversion from anti-Trump author to pro-Trump senator.
content: Few political reversals have been as dramatic and complete as the transformation of Senator JD Vance of Ohio from a self-proclaimed Never Trumper into former President Donald J. Trump’s new running mate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Jazmine Ulloa
title: Spaceman, Senator, V.P. Pick? Kamala Harris Sizes Up Mark Kelly.
description: The Arizona senator, a Navy veteran and former astronaut, has an almost impossibly strong political résumé. But an overlooked asset is his expertise on the Southern border.
content: The rugged border lands around Douglas, Ariz., dip through precipitous canyons and shoot skyward on rocky mountain walls, impossible terrain for a 30-foot steel bollard wall but not for the cartels smuggling people and contraband from Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
title: In Japan, Turning the Tables on Rude Customers
description: The country is famous for its hospitality. But businesses have had enough of people screaming at workers or tormenting them on social media.
content: The guests arrived 30 minutes before check-in time at a traditional hot springs inn a couple of hours north of Tokyo. When they saw a sign asking that customers wait in their cars, they demanded to know why they could not get their room key early.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: Shared Roots Helped Their Relationship Grow
description: Kevin Rivera and Selina Schultz knew each other growing up in Brooklyn. But he wasn’t quite on her radar until they were young adults.
content: Years before she became his wife, Selina Delgado Schultz was known to Kevin Justin Rivera as his best friend’s “cute cousin.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Roland Dumas Dies at 101; French Foreign Minister Tainted by Scandal
description: A lawyer and confidant of François Mitterrand, he was in the forefront of French politics for decades, only to be undone by his taste for the high life.
content: Roland Dumas, a former French foreign minister, agile political fixer and star defense lawyer whose taste for living large proved his undoing, died on July 3 in Paris. He was 101.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Battling Inflation, Russia Raises Key Interest Rate to 18 Percent
description: The move underscored the wartime risks for the Kremlin as the government pumps enormous sums of money into the Russian economy.
content: Russia’s central bank raised its key interest rate to 18 percent on Friday, the highest level in more than two years, in a sign of mounting concern in Moscow that the country’s wartime economy risked producing runaway inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: A Mysterious Plot Prompts a Rare Call From Russia to the Pentagon
description: Russia’s defense minister said he needed to talk to Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin about an alleged Ukrainian operation. What happened next remains murky.
content: Earlier this month, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III received an unusual request from an unlikely caller: His Russian counterpart wanted to talk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: The Obamas Called Kamala Harris. Cameras Rolled. Hokeyness Ensued.
description: Calling to offer their endorsement, the former president and first lady sounded like parents in a Lifetime movie talking to their child at summer camp.
content: Kamala Harris’s dizzying rollout as a presidential candidate somehow pulled off the rare feat of looking organic and organized, fun but without cringe-inducing artifice. Vibes shifted, memes spread, coconuts fell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: As Trump Looms, Blinken Aims to Reassure Allies on U.S. Commitment to Asia
description: Asian officials will press Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken about the former president and about Kamala Harris as he visits the region.
content: For three and a half years, President Biden and his aides have insisted that the United States is a Pacific power, and that its allies and partners in the region need not worry about Washington’s commitments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Vance Calls ‘Cat Ladies’ Remark ‘Sarcasm’ but Amplifies Birthrate Argument
description: Donald J. Trump’s running mate said in an interview with Megyn Kelly that Democrats believed they could “replace American children with immigrants.”
content: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, former President Donald J. Trump’s running mate, on Friday dug in on his past remarks lamenting that the United States was being run by Democrats without children, arguing that their party had become “very anti-child in their messaging and their public policy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: N.C.A.A. Settlement Agreement Reveals How Colleges Would Pay Athletes
description: The agreement, if approved by a federal judge, could deliver the final hammer blow to the amateur model of college athletics.
content: The N.C.A.A. and the richest college athletic conferences joined with plaintiffs’ lawyers on Friday to enter a $2.8 billion settlement agreement of their class-action antitrust lawsuit. The filing outlines in some detail how schools would be allowed for the first time to pay college athletes directly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: They’re Around Two Feet
description: Andy Kravis returns after a two-year absence with a lively puzzle.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Cherries for Black Forest Cake, Tomatoes for Gazpacho, Swordfish for Piccata
description: Something out there, something delicious, is speaking to you. Heed its call.
content: Good morning. I had smoked chicken wings on the menu for dinner, a beautiful salad of sliced, salted tomatoes with a fist of burrata and some drizzled balsamic vinegar, a Black Forest sheet cake (above) for dessert. That seemed enough — the cake, especially, with its blanket of whipped cream and studdings of cherry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas and Tariq Panja
title: Anger Lingers Over Positive Doping Tests for Chinese Swimmers
description: In Paris, Chinese swimmers have been under extra scrutiny by doping watchdogs, but that hasn’t satisfied competitors like American star Caeleb Dressel.
content: The days before the Olympic swimming competition are often a chance for the world’s best swimmers to share their hopes and expectations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Bergin
title: Whose Politics Are More Turbulent, America’s or Australia’s?
description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, citing the revolving door of prime ministers, said his own country was in no position to criticize the United States.
content: President Biden had just announced that he would bow out of the 2024 presidential race, throwing American politics into fresh tumult, when Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia was asked this week if he was worried about the United States, his nation’s most important ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susanna Timmons and John Otis
title: Here’s How The New York Times Is Bringing You the Olympics
description: Our reporters, photographers, editors and graphics team are in Paris to tell you the stories of triumph, disappointment and much more.
content: Whether you are one of the more than 10,000 elite athletes competing in the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics or an armchair admirer, it is go time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Precautions Failed to Halt Rail Sabotage
description: The attacks on several high-speed rail lines happened despite the sweeping mobilization of recent weeks.
content: The coordinated rail attacks that disrupted train travel in France on three high-speed lines Friday morning occurred despite intensive security precautions put into effect leading to the Olympics, which officially begin Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Aims to Restore Space Station Traffic After SpaceX and Boeing Problems
description: With the Falcon 9 rocket set to fly again, and testing of the Starliner capsule progressing, the agency is seeking to turn the page on a brief, troubled chapter in orbit.
content: NASA officials on Friday said they expected congestion at the International Space Station in the coming month, following a couple of weeks in which it seemed that the agency’s ability to transport astronauts to and from orbit was stuck in a holding pattern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: For Epidemics to Cross Oceans, Viruses on Ships Had to Beat the Odds
description: In the era when people traveled by sailing ship and steamer, illnesses usually burned themselves out before boats reached shore, a new study finds.
content: On Dec. 22, 1874, the H.M.S. Dido arrived in Fiji from Sydney, Australia, carrying about 200 people and an invisible payload. A king of Fiji and his son, who were on the ship, were infected with measles. When they debarked, they started an epidemic that killed 20,000 people in Fiji — up to one-fourth of the population — who had no immunity to the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Can Fees on Polluting Cars Clean the Air? London Has New Evidence.
description: The city’s expanded low-emissions zone, which was politically fraught, has cut emissions that contribute to health problems like asthma, new numbers show.
content: When pollution meets politics, efforts to clean up the air in the world’s big cities can bring risks as well as wins. London and New York got a taste of it this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Reid J. Epstein
title: Obama Endorses Harris for the Democratic Nomination
description: The former president, who had held back in the days immediately after President Biden left the race, joined the wave of support from Democratic leaders.
content: Former President Barack Obama endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination on Friday, delivering Ms. Harris perhaps the most important missing piece in what has been a cascade of support from her party’s most influential leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Americans Deserve More Debates and Transparency in This Election
description: Voters need a chance to see how the two candidates handle close public scrutiny in debates, interviews and informal events.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris, now the likely Democratic nominee, has the chance to encourage and embrace the kind of close examination that the public so far has had little opportunity to witness during the 2024 race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: A Bubbly Start, Then ‘Totally in Love’ by the Second Date
description: Kelly Lyles and Ron Verstappen coincidentally each sipped Champagne as they first chatted on the phone. They soon began sharing a glass daily.
content: Kelly Alise Lyles sipped Champagne while chatting with Ronald Bernardus Cornelis Franciscus Verstappen on the phone for the first time in December 2022. He had a glass in hand, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Town Famous for Royal and Hollywood Guests Is Ravaged by Wildfires
description: Fast-moving fires have destroyed a third of the buildings in the picturesque town of Jasper, Alberta, and its national park. But the mayor hopes to rebuild
content: Queen Elizabeth II vacationed there, as did her parents before her. Hollywood’s royalty were regular visitors, too. Marilyn Monroe filmed scenes for “River of No Return” there, and “The Emperor Waltz” brought Bing Crosby and Joan Fontaine to its golf courses and tennis courts. The mountains of Jasper, Alberta, have also stood in for peaks around the world in other movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Julie Turkewitz, Carlos Prieto, Clare Toeniskoetter, Olivia Natt, Mooj Zadie, Liz O. Baylen, Michael Benoist, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Is One Third of Venezuela’s Population About to Flee?
description: After years of repressive government and economic collapse, many Venezuelans think this weekend’s election might be different.
content: For years, Venezuelans have been living through one of the most severe economic collapses in modern history — one that has caused millions to flee the country. But this weekend, an election is offering many a real hope for change.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Campaign Advice for Kamala Harris
description: Readers offer an array of suggestions to the presumptive Democratic nominee. Also: Secret Service women; evangelicals and MAGA.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: How to Make Two Reality Stars Fall in Love? Cue a Tropical Beach
description: Reality TV staples like “Love Island” and “Bachelor in Paradise” often take place in luxury resorts to set the mood. But not all resorts love the attention.
content: Last summer, while filming an episode during the fifth season of the hit reality TV show “Love Island USA,” the executive producer Simon Thomas had a stroke of luck that most reality show producers could only dream of. It was golden hour, and two of the contestants — attractive young singles looking for love — were sitting on the veranda of the souped-up luxury resort that was the “Love Island” set. Exquisitely framed, they shared a tender, passionate kiss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Amid Deadly Listeria Outbreak, Boar’s Head Recalls Some Deli Meats
description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture is investigating whether Boar’s Head meat sliced at deli counters has played a role in an outbreak of listeriosis that has caused two deaths.
content: Amid an outbreak of listeria that has killed two people in the United States and sickened around three dozen others, Boar’s Head Products announced on Friday that it would recall more than 200,000 pounds of deli meat, including all liverwurst products currently available on the market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: What was with that heavy metal band? That was Gojira.
description: Gojira, a popular French band, became the first hard rock act to perform in an Olympic Games opening ceremony when it did a metal version of “Ah! Ça Ira,” a song that was popular during the French Revolution.
content: Gojira, a leading French heavy metal band, became the first hard rock act to perform in an Olympic Games opening ceremony when it did a metal version of “Ah! Ça Ira,” a song that was popular during the French Revolution. The band had reworked the song in collaboration with Victor le Masne, and performed with the opera singer Marina Viotti.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Chase to Bar Customers From Using Credit Cards for ‘Pay Later’ Loans
description: Financial regulators and consumer advocates frown upon using credit cards to pay off installment loans because of the risk that consumers will dig themselves further into debt.
content: JPMorgan Chase, the nation’s largest credit card issuer, will bar customers from using its credit cards to repay increasingly popular “buy now, pay later” installment loans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Flanagan
title: Why in the World Are We Sending 11-Year-Olds to the Olympics?
description: We don’t let preadolescent kids work. Why do we let them appear in the most high-pressure athletic contests on a global stage?
content: When the Olympics arrive and I hear the familiar kettle drums of the Games’ fanfare music I’m always catapulted back to 1972, when the Soviet gymnast Olga Korbut dazzled the world on the uneven parallel bars. As a kid, I watched transfixed. For the rest of the summer and to the great irritation of my parents and older siblings, I usurped the living room to practice my handstands, cartwheels and round-offs, all while fantasizing about the feel of a gold medal hanging from my neck. Demonstrations of astonishing athleticism will have that effect on children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Though Critical on Gaza, Trump Cites Good Relations With Netanyahu
description: The former president met with the Israeli leader in Florida, a day after his main opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris, and he both criticized Israel’s conduct of the war.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, who for months has urged Israel to end the war in the Gaza Strip as quickly as possible, said that he and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel remained on good terms after the two met on Friday, and that he would be a stronger ally of Israel than Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Natalie Kitroeff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: How the U.S. Captured One of Mexico’s Biggest Drug Lords
description: The improbable arrest of Ismael Zambada García, who for decades had evaded the authorities, at a small airport outside El Paso appears to be a tale of subterfuge and betrayal.
content: It sounded like a story ripped from a narco thriller: One of the biggest drug lords in Mexico was lured onto an airplane, flown across the border and presented to American federal agents by the son of his former partner in crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Is It Safe to Exercise When the Air Is Smoky?
description: The answer depends on your overall health, along with the length and intensity of your workout.
content: This week, smoke from wildfires burning in the Western United States and Canada is affecting air quality levels as far east as New England. When the air is smoky, it’s important to consider whether it’s safe to exercise outdoors — and how to protect yourself if you choose to head out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Museum of Natural History Says It Is Repatriating 124 Human Remains
description: The museum reports having hundreds of consultations with Native American groups and says it is also returning 90 objects.
content: The American Museum of Natural History said it was making progress on returning the human remains of nearly 2,200 Native Americans and thousands of tribal funerary objects, which became a top priority earlier this year in the wake of new federal regulations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Full Stands, Full Volume: The Olympics You Remember Are Back
description: Family, friends and fans were missing from two straight Covid Games. In Paris, one athlete said, competitors will have the kind of experience they dream about.
content: Tara Davis-Woodhall, a long jumper by trade and an entertainer at heart, gazed into the stands at Tokyo’s 68,000-seat Olympic stadium and decided she needed some noise. In a quixotic bid to inject even a small dose of spirit into a pandemic-stricken Summer Games, she began clapping her hands theatrically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caryn Ganz
title: 104 Shows. $260 Million. After 10 Years, Billy Joel Closes a Chapter.
description: The singer and songwriter, 75, wrapped his decade-long residency at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. Up next? A new era in his live career.
content: There’s a pause before Billy Joel steps onstage each night when he makes the subtle transition from low-key Everyman to world-renowned Piano Man. It’s just a few minutes of “not talking to anybody, not seeing anybody,” he said, mimicking waving off potential distractions. He makes sure he can hit his high notes. Then the roar of the crowd does the rest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel
title: K Street Pivots for a Possible Harris Administration
description: Lobbyists and lawyers are raising money for Vice President Kamala Harris, the likely Democratic presidential nominee, and assessing what her term might look like.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris has forsworn direct donations from lobbyists, but they are welcoming her candidacy and finding other ways to support it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Slow Down if You See These Dating ‘Yellow Flags’
description: Are they deal-breakers? Here is how to tell.
content: I’ve gotten a flurry of texts lately from friends who are dating, asking whether or not something is a “red flag.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabino Iglesias
title: 4 New Horror Novels Full of Ghosts, Monsters and Other Terrors
description: Our columnist reviews July’s horror releases.
content: Nicholas Belardes’s THE DEADING (Erewhon Books, 280 pp., $28) opens with good intentions: All Bernhard wanted when he poured poison into the Pacific was to protect his oysters from a deadly invasion of Atlantic driller snails. But things went south after his intervention. Yes, he killed a lot of snails, but many survived, migrated ashore and started attacking every living thing they found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Gail Lumet Buckley, Chronicler of Black Family History, Dies at 86
description: She wrote two books about multiple generations of her forebears, including her mother, Lena Horne.
content: Gail Lumet Buckley, who rather than follow her mother, Lena Horne, into show business, wrote two multigenerational books about their ambitious Black middle-class family, died on July 18 at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: What We Know About the Attacks on France’s Rail Network
description: Coordinated arson attacks on France’s national high-speed rail network have disrupted travel ahead of the opening ceremony for the Olympics in Paris.
content: Just hours before the opening ceremony of the Paris Olympics, France was rocked by a series of arson attacks on its rail network on Friday, stoking fears over security during the Games.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Ben Wikler
description: The July 26, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Ben Wikler. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Drops Opposition to International Criminal Court Warrant for Netanyahu
description: The new Labour government confirmed it would drop the previous government’s objection to I.C.C. arrest warrants for Israel’s Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the defense minister, Yoav Gallant.
content: Britain on Friday confirmed it was dropping plans to challenge the pursuit of an international warrant against Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, in the International Criminal Court, underscoring a shift in foreign policy under the country’s new prime minister, Keir Starmer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Draper
title: In JD Vance Country, an Addiction Scourge That Won’t Go Away

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Unnerving Changeability of JD Vance
description: He has a history of remaking himself to suit the men in his life.
content: In “Hillbilly Elegy,” the 2016 memoir that made JD Vance a celebrity, he described constantly remaking his childhood self to fit the rotating cast of father figures his unsound mother brought into their lives. “With Steve, a midlife-crisis sufferer with an earring to prove it, I pretended earrings were cool — so much so that he thought it appropriate to pierce my ear,” Vance wrote. “With Chip, an alcoholic police officer who saw my earring as a sign of ‘girlieness,’ I had thick skin and loved police cars. With Ken, an odd man who proposed to Mom three days into their relationship, I was a kind brother to his two children.”

content: An enormous wildfire in Northern California has destroyed buildings, left at least two people injured and prompted evacuation orders for thousands of people as it raged in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada. title: Book Club: Let’s Talk About ‘The Talented Mr. Ripley’
description: Patricia Highsmith’s classic thriller mixes glamour, betrayal, self-invention and murder. What’s not to love?
content: Patricia Highsmith’s 1955 thriller “The Talented Mr. Ripley” follows a young, down-on-his-luck scammer, Tom Ripley, who is looking to reverse his fortunes. When he receives a job offer to go to Italy and retrieve Dickie Greenleaf, a rich socialite on an endless holiday, Tom finds the perfect opportunity to work his way into the upper crust. But as he becomes more and more obsessed with Dickie and Dickie’s life, the breezy getaway turns into something much more sinister, sending them down a dangerous path.

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Partner Told Me About His Fights With His Ex. I Think I’m on Her Side.
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how partners can evaluate their romantic histories together — and be honest and respectful in their assessments.
content: My partner and I each had several significant relationships before we met. We’re both in therapy and have learned a lot from that, so we’re very comfortable processing past relationships together. One of my partner’s past relationships soured quickly, which led to years of resentment and frustration before it ended. When he processes past arguments with his ex, he sometimes says she ‘‘picked a fight,’’ but when he tells the story, I quietly find that I’m often on her side. I find it odd that he, with all his otherwise tremendous self-awareness, cannot move past what to me feels like a somewhat skewed take on someone else’s valid frustrations.
source.name: The New York Times
